p: However, for palliative care clinicians on the frontlines, our practice has changed entirely. While we are accustomed to tolerating prognostic uncertainty in our decision-making, COVID’s trajectories are less clear than those of cancer and heart failure. We’ve also been separated from the sights and sounds of our patients and their loved ones. We’re either working virtually or not regularly going into patients’ rooms to conserve personal protective equipment (PPE). Families are no longer at the bedside. As are all specialties, palliative care is adapting its clinical tools to COVID’s shifting reality. More than ever, though, data will be essential to guide our response moving forward.
